firstChapter.htmlHeader: Insect bites and stings: Summary
firstChapter.htmlStringContent:
• Insects bite by puncturing the skin with piercing mouthparts (for example mosquitos and bedbugs) or by lacerating the skin (for example horseflies and midges).
  • Stinging insects (such as bees and wasps) cause a sting by injecting venom from a sac attached to a barbed or non-barbed stinger into the skin.
  • Most insect bite reactions resolve completely within hours, but occasionally can persist for months for example if tick mouthparts are retained in the skin or if infestations are untreated.
  • Complications from insect bites and stings include local skin trauma, allergic reactions, systemic toxicity (from multiple stings), transmission of infectious diseases (such as Lyme disease or malaria) and secondary skin infections.
  • Most insect stings result in minor local reactions which usually last from a few hours to several days.
    • In some people, large local skin reactions, or potentially life-threatening systemic reactions including anaphylaxis can occur.
  • Immediate admission should be arranged for anyone who:
    • Is suspected of having a systemic reaction to an insect bite or sting — angio-oedema or anaphylaxis should be treated urgently while awaiting emergency transfer to hospital.
    • Has been stung on the face or mucous membranes, and is at risk of airway obstruction or compromised vision. 
  • Consider referral or seeking specialist advice if a person with a bite or sting has 
    • Has had a previous systemic allergic reaction from the same bite or sting.
    • Has a fever or persisting lesions from a bite or sting from an insect outside the UK.
    • Been stung by an insect which is unsual or from a tropical or subtropical locale.   
  • Referral to an allergy specialist should be arranged for people who have had a systemic reaction to an insect bite or sting.
    • Discuss with an allergy specialist the need to refer people who have had a large local reaction.
  • For all insect bites and stings, where admission is not required:
    • Consider if tetanus prophylaxis is appropriate.
    • Remove visible stingers as quickly as possible by scraping sideways with a fingernail, a piece of card or a credit card.
    • Remove ticks visible in the skin as soon as possible (if the person is not known to be allergic to ticks) — grasp the tick close to skin with a pair of forceps, tweezers or specialist tick remover and pull perpendicular to the skin, gently but firmly. Consider the possibility of Lyme disease.
    • Clean the area - application of a cold compress may help reduce local pain and swelling.
    • Advise good hygiene and avoidance of scratching to prevent secondary infection.
    • Reassess if the person is unwell, develops signs of infection or has severe pain.  
  • If bites are thought to be due to infestation, advice the person that the source needs to be eradicated, for example, pest control services should be contacted for control of bedbug infestations.
  • If the person has a transient localised reaction to the bite or sting:
    • Usually, no treatment other than simple first aid is required. Oral paracetamol or ibuprofen (to ease pain), topical corticosteroids (such as hydrocortisone) and oral antihistamines (such as chlorphenamine) to reduce itching are often recommended, but evidence for these treatments is lacking.
  • If the person has a large local reaction to the bite or sting:
    • Oral antihistamines and corticosteroids are often recommended as treatment, but use is generally off-label and supporting evidence is lacking.
  • If secondary infection develops treat cellulitis in primary care with oral antibiotics in accordance with local prescribing protocols.
    • Consider the need for admission if cellulitis is severe, the person is severely immunocompromised or treatment in primary care fails.
